This section will take a brief look at the rich field of lexical compounds, but will not tackle the matter of inflectional morphology or lexical derivations.[1] A great many Tibetan words are in fact compounds which for the most part have a clear enough etymology. The following pages will set out the main rules for the construction of words that are valuable for both the spoken and the written languages.

[1] These two domains are actually more relevant to a diachronic perspective or a study of Tibetan etymology, and are not directly useful for learning Modern Spoken Tibetan. For further information, see Kesang Gyurmé, Le Clair Miroir: Enseignement de la Grammaire Tibétaine, trans. and commentaries by Heather Stoddard and Nicolas Tournadre, 2nd ed. (Arvillard: Editions PrajñƒÅ, 1994). In English, see Stephan Beyer, The Classical Tibetan Language (Albany: State University of New York Press, 1992).
